related_acts: Recording of Evidence by Sound Recording Machine Act
paragraphs:
[1]
Reed, J.
: The respondent brings a motion to have paragraphs struck from affidavits that have been filed in support of the applicant's application. The applicant challenges a decision of the Regional Safety Officer, dated April 25, 1997. The applicant filed affidavits sworn by two witnesses who gave evidence to the Regional Safety Officer; those witnesses were Messrs. McClellan and Mayor. The applicant claims that the evidence of those witnesses was ignored by the Regional Safety Officer. The respondent seeks to have the relevant portions of the affidavits, and the corresponding paragraphs of the applicant's memorandum of fact and law, struck from the record. It is argued that if the applicant wants to rely on the transcript of the proceedings before the Regional Safety Officer, it must file the relevant portions of the transcript of that hearing, and not rely on the affidavit evidence of those who appeared as witnesses.

[2]
Counsel for the respondent has obtained, from the Regional Safety Officer, a copy of the tape recording of the proceedings before that officer and has offered it to counsel for the applicant. She does not seek to have the tape recordings transcribed for the respondent's purposes. She does not contest the accuracy of the statements made in the affidavits filed in support of the applicant's position by Messrs. McClellan and Mayor. Counsel for the respondent's position is that the applicant has an obligation to produce the best evidence in support of its claim to the court, and this requires it to pay the cost of transcribing the tape recordings and to include the relevant portions of such transcript in its application record.

[3]
I have not been persuaded that the
Federal Court Rules
regarding judicial review applications require such. I leave aside the question of whether a transcription,
by a party
, of a tape recording of the proceeding is a transcript. Counsel for the applicant argues that only a duly certified copy of the transcript, by an independent person, qualifies as such. The references cited in support of this position were:
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (Nfld. T.D.);
Recording of Evidence by Sound Recording Machine Act
, R.S.S. 1978, c.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (U.S. Ct. of App.).

[4]
The decisions that this court is asked to review, by way of judicial review, are varied in their content and procedural context. On some occasions official transcripts are prepared; on others, there may not even be a tape-recording of the proceeding available. In some cases, where there is a formal record that has been kept, the decision maker does not go to the expense of providing a transcription of the proceedings until after an application for judicial review has been commenced and a request pursuant to rules 1612 or 1613 made.

[5]
I think the respondent's motion can be decided on a very narrow basis. Rules 1606(2)(d) requires that an application record contain "the portions of any transcript of evidence to be used by the applicant at the hearing". The applicant, in this case, does not intend to rely on a transcript of the proceedings (if the tape recording that exists, once transcribed, qualifies as a transcript). The applicant has obtained affidavit evidence from two witnesses who presented evidence to the decision maker. It is that evidence upon which the applicant seeks to rely in making its claim. This does not preclude the respondent from challenging the accuracy of the affidavits by cross-examining the affiants, or by filing its own transcription of the tape recording of the proceeding. At the same time, the
Rules
do not preclude the applicant proceeding as it has done, based on affidavit evidence, without going to the expense of preparing a transcription of the tape recording.

[6]
The sources cited to me concerning the best evidence rule include:
The Law of Evidence in Canada
, Sopinka and Lederman, Butterworths at 929-940;
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  W.A.C. 398; 94 C.C.C.(3d) 574 ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (U.S. Ct. of  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  does not apply to require an applicant to prepare its application record in the manner that counsel for the respondent seeks to impose on counsel for the applicant.

[7]
The decision in
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.A.) deals with the obligation of decision makers (in that case the Public Service Commission) to have a verbatim record made, either by electronic recording or shorthand notes, of the proceedings before it. The court notes that under the then relevant
Federal Court Rules
, if a tribunal has caused its proceedings to be recorded and has in its possession a transcript of them, then,
the tribunal
is required to forward that transcript to the court as part of the record. The decision also indicates that where there is no statutory or other legal obligation on a decision maker to transcribe its proceedings, an applicant has the right to require the production of shorthand notes or tape recordings of the proceedings, if they exist, and may transcribe them at this or her own expense for use before the court. I do not read that decision as stating that the only way an applicant can present evidence of what was said to a decision maker, when a tape recording has been made of the proceeding, is by producing a transcription of that tape recording.

[8]
For the reasons given the motion will be dismissed. Counsel for the applicant asked that costs be awarded in any event of the cause. Rule 1618 provides that costs are not awarded in respect of judicial review applications unless special reasons are shown. Special reasons were not argued before me. I leave this matter to be decided at a later date in the context of the application as a whole, should counsel decide that this is a situation in which he wishes to argue that special reasons exist for awarding costs.
Motion dismissed.
Editor: Jana A. Andersen/kaw
[End of document]

statutes: Recording of Evidence by Sound Recording Machine Act , R.S.S. 1978, c.
legal_issues: The permissible form of evidence in judicial review proceedings, specifically whether affidavit evidence is sufficient in lieu of a formal transcript.
The obligation of an applicant to produce the 'best evidence' when a record of proceedings exists in a non-transcript format.
The interpretation of court rules regarding the content of an application record, particularly concerning transcripts of evidence.
Whether a duty exists to transcribe a recording of proceedings for inclusion in a judicial review application, and who bears the cost of such transcription.
The application of the 'best evidence rule' in the context of judicial review and the admissibility of alternative forms of proof.
The circumstances under which costs may be awarded in judicial review applications.
factual_background: An applicant is challenging a decision made by a Regional Safety Officer on April 25, 1997.
The applicant submitted affidavits from two witnesses, McClellan and Mayor, who also provided evidence to the Regional Safety Officer.
The respondent believes the applicant should have submitted a transcript of the proceedings before the Regional Safety Officer instead of relying on the affidavits.
The respondent obtained a tape recording of the proceedings before the Regional Safety Officer and offered it to the applicant's counsel.
The respondent does not dispute the accuracy of the statements within the affidavits provided by McClellan and Mayor.
The applicant relies on the affidavit evidence of the two witnesses as the basis for its claim.
The proceedings before the Regional Safety Officer are sometimes officially transcribed, and sometimes are only tape recorded, or not recorded at all.
In some instances, transcripts are not created until after a judicial review application is filed.

Applicants: The Regional Safety Officer ignored evidence presented by witnesses McClellan and Mayor.
Affidavit evidence from McClellan and Mayor should be sufficient for the application without requiring a transcript of the original proceedings.
Only a duly certified transcript by an independent person qualifies as a 'transcript', not a transcription of a tape recording by a party.
The Federal Court Rules do not require the applicant to pay for transcribing the tape recording to present evidence.
The applicant is relying on the evidence *given* to the Regional Safety Officer, as captured in the affidavits, and is not attempting to rely on a transcript of the proceedings themselves.
Respondents: The applicant must produce the best evidence, which requires transcribing the tape recording of the proceedings before the Regional Safety Officer and including the relevant portions in the application record.
If the applicant wants to rely on the proceedings before the Regional Safety Officer, it must file a transcript, not affidavit evidence.
The applicant has an obligation to pay the cost of transcribing the tape recording.

court_analysis: The central issue was whether the applicant was obligated to provide a transcript of a tape recording from the original proceedings to support its application, or if it could rely on affidavits from witnesses who testified at those proceedings. The court found that Federal Court Rule 1606(2)(d) only requires the inclusion of transcripts *to be used* at the hearing, and the applicant was not intending to use a transcript but rather rely on the affidavit evidence.

The court distinguished between the existence of a transcript and the obligation to *produce* one. It reasoned that the rules do not preclude an applicant from proceeding based on affidavit evidence without incurring the expense of transcription, even if a tape recording exists.

The court rejected the respondent’s argument based on the “best evidence rule,” finding it inapplicable in this context. It noted that the rule doesn't mandate a specific method for preparing an application record.

The court clarified that the prior case of <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> (F.C.A.) did not establish that a transcription was the *only* way to present evidence of what was said to the decision-maker when a tape recording exists; it only addressed the obligations of decision-makers to provide transcripts when they already exist and are in their possession.

The court emphasized the varied nature of judicial review proceedings, noting that official transcripts are not always prepared or even available, and decision-makers often delay transcription until a request is made. This context supported the court’s decision not to impose a transcription requirement in this case.
The court dismissed the motion, concluding that the applicant was entitled to rely on the affidavit evidence without being compelled to transcribe the tape recording at its own expense.
final_outcome: Costs were not awarded at this time, and the matter of costs was left to be decided at a later date in the context of the application as a whole.
